Comments_List: Basics of probability modeling (poisson - temporal and spacial, queuing theory, markov processes, random incidence, etc.) applied to realistic policy settings (housing, counter terrorism, needle exchange, AIDS testing, etc)
Was able to look at seemingly complex problems from a simple step based approach.
I think I already filled this one out.

In-class instruction is excellent. Prof Kaplan is consistently enthusiastic and knows the material inside and out. He uses that knowledge to present each model with great clarity.

A weakness of the course, for me, however, was that I often found problem sets and test questions to be more difficult than those we did in class. Part of this was, no doubt, due to not having Prof Kaplan around to explain them for me. One approach that might help would be to have students spend a few minutes attempting to set up models themselves in class before Prof Kaplan's explanation. This might help us develop the right instincts when faced with a new problem without an expert guide.

I would recommend it but I would like to emphasize the need to have strong basis in statistics and calculus (better if the person has taken the class before this one 'Probability Modeling & Statistics').
Definitely to any student willing to do a bit of math and a lot of thinking about how to translate complex, real problems into simple mathematical concepts.
